ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

INDUSTRIAL AND COMMERCIAL LEASES
(Rental rebates)


    1. Mr S. Chandra Das asked the Minister for National Development (a) whether he proposes to extend the 15% rental rebate for industrial and commercial leases which was granted for one year, and, if so, for how long; and (b) whether further reductions are being considered.

    2. Mrs Yu-Foo Yee Shoon asked the Minister for National Development whether the Housing and Development Board will (i) extend the rental rebate for HDB shops and (ii) increase the rebate of 15% to 30%, depending on the location of shops, for the year 1986 to 1987.

     The Minister for National Development (Mr Teh Cheang Wan): Mr Speaker, Sir, since Questions 1 and 2 from the Members for Chong Boon and Yuhua are similar, I will answer both questions together. The answers are:

    (a) The HDB will extend by another 21 months, up to 31st December 1987, the 15% rental rebate for HDB industrial and commercial premises.

    (b) The present rental rebate of 15% plus the 50% property rebate that has just been announced represent a very substantial reduction in rentals for tenants of HDB industrial and commercial premises. With the rebates, the rentals of these premises are generally lower than the current market rentals payable by new tenants of HDB premises. There is therefore no plan at present for the rental rebate to be increased further.

     Mr J.B. Jeyaretnam (Anson): May I ask the Minister why is it necessary to relate rentals all the time to rentals in the private sector?

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Mr Speaker, Sir, I did not relate the rentals to the private sector. I said "new HDB tenants", not the private sector.

RESETTLEMENT OF PIG FARMERS IN PUNGGOL
(Plans for use of land)


    3. Mr Ng Kah Ting asked the Minister for National Development (a) how many small-time pig farmers in Punggol have been resettled up to the latest convenient date; (b) what is the acreage of land left vacant; and (c) whether there are any proposals to have such land utilized for agricultural purposes; and, if so, what will be the activities and conditions and whether any expenditure will be incurred.

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Mr Speaker, Sir, since the announcement of the Government's policy in March 1984 in this House to phase out pig farming, 65 small pig farms have been resettled from Punggol. The land left vacant by the resettled pig farms in Punggol is about 22 hectares.

    Punggol has been earmarked for HDB housing development. The vacated land in Punggol will therefore be tendered out for short-term non-pollutive agricultural activities, such as vegetable cultivation. The necessary infrastructure such as roads, electricity and water supply are already provided. Hence, any development expenditure will be minimal.

     Mr Ng Kah Ting (Punggol): Mr Speaker, Sir, may I ask of the Hon. Minister how long will this vacant land be leased out for other agricultural purposes?

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Sir, about three to five years.

HAWKER LICENCES
(Particulars)


    4. Encik Abbas Abu Amin asked the Minister for the Environment (a) how many licensed hawkers there were on 31st December 1985; (b) how many hawker licences will be issued in 1986; (c) what are the criteria for approving applications for such licences; and (d) what types of stalls are available to new licencees.

Column: 557



     The Senior Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment (Mr Eugene Yap Giau Cheng) (for the Minister for the Environment): Mr Speaker, Sir, I am answering on behalf of my Minister.

    The number of licensed hawkers as at 31st December 1985 was 25,511, consisting of 13,236 market produce hawkers, 9,249 cooked food hawkers and 3,026 piece and sundry goods hawkers.

    New hawker licences are issued only to resettlement cases and those who qualify under the hardship scheme. As the HDB and the MOE will not be building any more hawker centres, the number of new hawker licences to be issued in 1986 will depend on the number of vacancies that become available when existing stallholders give up their stalls.

    The criteria for approving applications for cooked food stalls are based on the applicant's financial position, age and the number of dependants the applicant has to support.

    As at the end of February 1986, there were vacancies for 1,535 market produce stalls, 357 cooked food stalls and 144 piece and sundry goods stalls. 120 food stalls are set aside for resettlement cases each year. The remaining vacancies are available to those who satisfy the means test for hardship.

     Encik Abbas Abu Amin (Pasir Panjang): Sir, would the Senior Parliamentary Secretary consider offering some of the vacant stalls to the older retrenched workers?

     Mr Eugene Yap Giau Cheng: Mr Speaker, Sir, I am afraid the answer has to be no. To simply give a retrenched worker a stall because he has been retrenched or because he is unemployed is really not the only way to help this retrenched worker. There are many other more suitable and better ways to help retrenched workers. Having said that, if a worker is retrenched and finds himself in serious financial hardship, then he may together with all the other hardship cases, apply for consideration by the Hawkers Department. What we normally do is to consider his application according to his age, financial position, total family income, the number of

Column: 558

dependants he has, and so on. If he qualifies, then we will consider him for a stall, but he has to wait for it.

REDUCTION OF ROAD TAX
(Consideration)


    5. Dr Arthur Beng Kian Lam asked the Minister for Communications and Information, as the target that car growth should not exceed the rate of increase in road capacity has been attained, and taking into consideration the fact that there are fewer vehicles on our roads today than a year ago, whether the Minister will consider a reduction in road tax at this time of economic recession.

     The Minister for Communications (Dr Yeo Ning Hong): Mr Speaker, Sir, Government's objective in land transportation is to ensure that our roads remain free from serious traffic jams, so that people and goods can move about quickly and efficiently. We must continually keep the growth of cars within manageable levels. Otherwise, corrective measures will be difficult and painful.

    Therefore, we must look at the long-term trend in the growth of cars rather than in any one particular year. Last year, even with the recession, the increase in the number of cars was about 2%. With a recovery of the economy, there is no reason to believe that there will not be a sharp increase in the number of cars. It is therefore reckless to reduce road taxes to stimulate an increase in cars.

    In the meantime, Government continues to push ahead with the building of roads and expressways as well as the construction of the MRT.

     Dr Arthur Beng Kian Lam (Fengshan): Mr Speaker, Sir, does the Minister not agree that the reduction of road tax, like petrol price and taxi fares which the Ministry has rescinded, will result in a significant reduction in the cost of living and cost of doing business in Singapore, which is the goal of the Government?

     Dr Yeo Ning Hong: Sir, the answer is yes. The reduction of petrol prices which has already taken place has indeed con-

Column: 559

tributed to the lowering of the cost of living and cost of operations.

     Mr Chng Hee Kok (Radin Mas): Sir, will the Minister give an assurance then that road tax will not be increased so long as the relative growth rates between cars and roads are maintained?

     Dr Yeo Ning Hong: Sir, I can give the assurance, as the Member has said, provided that the growth of cars is within manageable levels, relative to the amount of roads to be built over the next five or six years. And that will represent the limit of land available in Singapore for roads.

     Mr Chng Hee Kok: Sir, the rates we are talking about are the relative growth rates between roads and cars. Does the Minister intend to peg the increase in road tax to some kind of ratio between the increase in cars and increase in roads?

     Dr Yeo Ning Hong: Sir, we have to manage our land transportation policies rationally. With about 15% more roads, as far as the potential of land is concerned, we will have to watch the situation carefully and continue to encourage the use of more efficient land transport systems.

     Dr Arthur Beng Kian Lam: Sir, will the Minister consider reduction of taxes for goods vehicles and other vehicles used for business?

     Dr Yeo Ning Hong: Sir, like all vehicles using our roads, goods vehicles too have to pay their proportionate level of contribution. Many of these taxes for goods vehicles have been kept the same ever since 1966. So in effect, taking into account inflation, the level of taxation has indeed been reduced as a result of the passing years.

REVIEW OF TAXI FARES
(Plans)


    6. Dr Wong Kwei Cheong asked the Minister for Communications and Information if there are plans to review the taxi fare structure, in view of the drastic reduction in world oil prices.

     Dr Yeo Ning Hong: Mr Speaker, Sir, since June last year, taxi fares have been determined by taxi drivers through their

Column: 560

companies and associations. So far, my Ministry has not received any request from taxi organizations to change the fare structure.

    Sir, the Member for Cairnhill may be interested to note that the decrease in diesel pump price this year is about 15 cents per litre. The average fuel consumption is about 10 km per litre. For an average trip of about 6 km, that works out to a saving of 9.1 cents for the taxi driver.

     Mr Chng Hee Kok: Sir, will the Minister agree to allow taxi drivers to set their own rates without reference to the Registry of Vehicles?

     Dr Yeo Ning Hong: Sir, the Ministry will allow the taxi drivers to set their fares. But we have not received any request so far.

     Dr Wong Kwei Cheong (Cairnhill): Sir, the Minister has mentioned that he has not received any request from taxi drivers for fare increases. Will he consider such a request from passengers?

     Dr Yeo Ning Hong: Sir, I think it must be obvious that commuters will always ask for decreases in taxi fares. But in this particular case, the savings is relatively small.

TENDER PRICES FOR HDB CONTRACTORS


    7. Mr S. Vasoo asked the Minister for National Development whether the tender prices for Housing and Development Board contracts are lower now; and, if so, whether the HDB will consider passing the benefits to future flat purchasers.

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Mr Speaker, Sir, while prices of building materials have generally fallen in the last two years, tenders awarded by the HDB to its building contractors have remained relatively constant. This is due mainly to the introduction of improved building features and better finishes to HDB flats, such as the use of better quality aluminium sliding windows, replacement of mild steel casement windows in kitchens with aluminium windows, extension of glazed wall tiles to ceiling height, etc. In addition, resettlement cost has increased by 30% since March 1985. This adds to the

Column: 561

development cost of HDB flats. At present selling prices, HDB flats are already subsidized by Government. Any reduction in the selling prices without a corresponding fall in the building cost will mean a further increase in the level of Government subsidy on public housing. This is not possible at this time when Government is lowering taxes and reducing its revenue collection.

     Mr Chiam See Tong (Potong Pasir): Can the Minister please cite the three awards for HDB tender for construction of flats in 1984, or any figures for last year to show whether the prices are going up or down?

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: Mr Speaker, Sir, I have said just now that the awards tendered by HDB have remained more or less constant.

PUNGGOL NEW TOWN
(Building of)


    8. Mr Ng Kah Ting asked the Minister for National Development whether and when a New Town will be built in the Punggol Constituency.

     The Senior Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for National Development (Mr Lee Yiok Seng)(for the Minister for National Development): Mr Speaker, Sir, I am answering on behalf of my Minister.

    (In Mandarin): This is a question relating to the development in Punggol. The HDB plans to build a New Town in Punggol. However, the development of this New Town is not expected to take place until after 1995.

     Mr Ng Kah Ting( In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I would like to ask the Senior Parliamentary Secretary whether he can tell the House the size of the land earmarked for the development of the future New Town in Punggol. Also what is the number of flats to be built, and how many residents can be accommodated in this New Town?

     Mr Lee Yiok Seng( In Mandarin): About 45,000 flats will be built in this new town, and about 180,000 residents can be expected to be accommodated there.

     Mr Yeo Choo Kok (Delta)( In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, a supplementary question. I would like to ask the Senior Parliamentary Secretary whether this New Town will be a new Punggol Constituency or a new Kankar Constituency?

     Mr Lee Yiok Seng( In Mandarin): In such matters, the HDB usually will respect the views of the grassroots leaders and the MPs concerned. RESETTLEMENT OF SHOPKEEPERS
(Compensation and assistance)


    9. Mr Ng Kah Ting asked the Minister for National Development (a) whether he will enlighten the House on the number of cases of resettlement, particularly of those shopkeepers who have, due to the recession and lack of capital, opted for cash compensation; and (b) whether the same compensation will be given in respect of shophouses which were built before World War II and are of a temporary nature, as for those defined as permanent structures; and, if not, what other assistance is being contemplated.

     Mr Lee Yiok Seng (for the Minister for National Development): Mr Speaker, Sir, again I will answer on behalf of my Minister.

    (In Mandarin): There are two parts. In answer to the first part, in 1985 there were 535 or about 15.4% non-residential resettlement cases, ie, traders or businessmen who did not accept alternative accommodation but opted for cash compensation. Among them, there were about 310 shopkeepers. Those who opt for cash compensation need not give their reasons, and therefore the Resettlement Department has no means of knowing whether these people made their decision because of a lack of cash, because of recession, or for other reasons.

    To answer the second part, under the current resettlement policy, when non-residential property or commercial pro-

Column: 563

perty or permanent structures under rent control are affected by resettlement, they could choose to have either an alternative accommodation or cash compensation. Those who occupy temporary structures can only get reallocation of accommodation; they cannot get cash compensation.

NEIGHBOURHOOD POLICE POST AT AYER RAJAH ESTATE


    10. Encik Abbas Abu Amin asked the Minister for Home Affairs whether his Ministry will set up a Neighbourhood Police Post earlier than scheduled at Ayer Rajah Estate (Dover Road).

     The Minister for Home Affairs (Prof. S. Jayakumar): Mr Speaker, Sir, a total of 91 Neighbourhood Police Posts will be set up in phases by 1989. So far, 34 NPPs have been set up in four Police Divisions, namely, Toa Payoh, Paya Lebar, Jurong and Queenstown. The rest of the NPPs will be set up at a rate of 14-15 per year.

    The NPP for Pasir Panjang Constituency will be built at Block 3, Dover Crescent, in the second half of this year. We are not able to set it up ahead of schedule due to manpower, training and other constraints.

ARRESTED PERSONS
(Procedure on Contact with family and counsel)


    11. Mr J.B. Jeyaretnam asked the Minister for Home Affairs whether his Ministry will issue a directive to all police stations that anyone arrested and brought to a police station should be given immediately an opportunity to contact his home or his relatives and even an Advocate and Solicitor of his choice.

     Prof. Jayakumar: Mr Speaker, Sir, there is no need for such a directive. Existing police procedures are adequate. They allow an arrested person to contact his family and counsel of his choice.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Mr Speaker, Sir, is the Minister saying that this existing police procedure, which he says exists, is complied with by all police stations, by police officers there? Is he aware that persons had been detained for up to 48 hours,

Column: 564

which is the time under the Constitution for a person to be detained before he can be brought to Court, without facilities given to the accused persons to contact their homes or their relatives? If he is not aware, I will give him a number of instances.

     Prof. Jayakumar: Mr Speaker, Sir, I have pointed out that police procedures allow an arrested person to contact his family and counsel of his choice. The precise moment as to when he is allowed to do so must, of course, depend on the circumstances of each case, the interests of the arrested person as well as public interest and the duty of the police to effectively investigate the case.

    The Member for Anson referred to the Constitution. The Constitution says:

    'Where a person is arrested he shall be informed as soon as may be of the grounds of his arrest and shall be allowed to consult and be defended by a legal practitioner of his choice.' The law is complied with in all cases, and in the overwhelming majority of cases there is no problem whatsoever as the police have allowed arrested persons to contact their family or friends immediately.

    There may be some instances where it may not be possible and it may not be advisable to allow an arrested person to contact his family immediately. These would be cases where police investigations are not yet completed, or where contact with family and friends immediately would result in tampering or destruction of evidence, or where they involve conspirators or accomplices such that contacting family or counsel immediately upon arrrest would lead to the flight and disappearance of accomplices or friends. So, Mr Speaker, Sir, a balance must be struck between the interest of the arrested person and the interest of the public. We cannot go the way some Western countries have gone, where the rights of the criminal havebeen placed on a higher pedestal than the rights of victims and the rights of society at large to live in a crime-free environment-

     Mr Jeyaretnam: What crime-free environment?

Column: 565



     Prof. Jayakumar: - and in a state of law, order and security.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Does the Minister realize that most of his answer really is specious? Will the Minister say whether he is aware or not? If he is not and he wants details, I will give it to him - cases where persons have been detained for more than 24 hours without any opportunity to contact their homes. And it is not in serious crimes. It is even in arrests for the slightest reasons.

    Is the Minister not assuming in his answer that every person arrested by the police is a criminal? Is he saying that every person who is arrested is charged immediately in court? Does he not know of persons who have been detained for 36 hours and then released without any charge being brought against them? What is the objection in these cases to their being allowed to phone home or to their friends or relatives? May we have sensible answers from the Minister?

     Prof. Jayakumar: Mr Speaker, Sir, I have already said that in the overwhelming majority of cases arrested persons are allowed to contact their friends and relatives immediately. It is in the category of cases where accomplices and conspirators would flee, evidence and weapons would be secreted away or destroyed, where the exercise of the right to consult counsel or to inform relatives is conditioned by the necessity to complete Police investigations. If the Member for Anson has information of cases which he considers that the law has been transgressed or the right has been delayed without justification, he should let us have the particulars and, of course, I will investigate it.

    But the point I want to stress is that the Government must ensure that the interest of the public and of maintaining law, order and security must have priority when we seek to strike a balance between the rights of arrested persons and the rights of the public at large.

    If I may quote, Sir, from a former President of the Federal Court of Malaysia and a leading constitutional authority on

Column: 566

Malaysian/Singapore Constitutional law. This is what he has to say:

    'The phrase "shall be allowed" clearly indicates that the right of the community for peace and tranquility is a greater right and therefore must be given priority to the right of individual persons. It is obvious that what is "reasonable time" and what are "reasonable restrictions" are incapable of ascertainment in advance. These criteria could only be decided with reference to each particular case, the facts of which may vary from case to case.'

    If I may quote from another leading authority, a leading case on this question. This is what the Courts had to say. The Court said:

    'The right of an arrested person to consult his lawyer begins from the moment of arrest but I am of the opinion that the right cannot be exercised immediately after the arrest. A balance has to be struck between the right of the arrested person to consult his lawyer on the one hand and on the other the duty of the Police to protect the public from wrongdoers by apprehending them and collecting whatever evidence exists against them. ... The interest of justice is as important as the interest of arrested persons and it is well-known that criminal elements are deterred most of all by the certainty of detection, arrest and punishment.'

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Minister has asked for examples. Does he not know that someone was arrested on the 1st of March in the early hours of the morning, and because he did not happen to have his identity card on him he was hauled off to the police station, and he was locked up until 3.00 pm that afternoon? What was the reason for that, and what was the reason for preventing him from getting in touch with his family?

     Prof. Jayakumar: Mr Speaker, Sir, I think Members and viewers who are watching these proceedings must realize that it is manifestly unreasonable to ask the Minister to discuss details of a case of which he has not been given notice by the Member for Anson. If the Member for Anson feels strongly that this is a case which is typical in point, then he should let us have the particulars, send it to my Ministry, and I will cause an investigation to see whether this is a case where there has been an unjustifiable delay. But his question was phrased in general terms and I have given what I believe is a proper answer.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Would the Minister say that was a reasonable detention of this

Column: 567

man on the facts that I have given him - non-possession of an identity card -

     An hon. Member: Sit down!

     Mr Jeyaretnam: And the man was not charged when he was released at 3.00 pm that afternoon. On those facts, will the Minister say whether that detention was lawful and justified?

     Prof. Jayakumar: Mr Speaker, Sir, I would have thought that any legally trained person -

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Answer the question. Is that reasonable?

     Prof. Jayakumar: Mr Speaker, Sir, if the Member for Anson wants an answer he should avoid interjecting rudely and in such an undignified manner. He has said that he knows of a case on which he has supplied me with very sparse particulars. If I am to give a sensible and considered reply, I would want to know all the facts -

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Non-possession of identity card.

     Prof. Jayakumar: - pertaining to that case and not just the meagre facts supplied by the Member for Anson.

NON-PAYMENT OF INCENTIVE PAY
(Particulars)


    12. Dr Wong Kwei Cheong asked the Minister for Finance (a) what is the total number of employees affected by the cut in the half-month incentive pay recently announced by the Government; (b) what will be the total savings; and (c) whether the cut will further aggravate the recession by reducing the purchasing power of a sizeable proportion of the working population.

     The Minister for Finance (Dr Hu Tsu Tau): Mr Speaker, Sir, following consultations with the public sector unions, the Government had recently announced that the incentive pay for 1986 will be withdrawn in respect of monthly-rated public employees. The matter will continue to be pursued with the daily-rated unions.

    The estimated number of public sector employees affected, including both monthly-rated and daily-rated employees,

Column: 568

would be 142,444. The total savings is estimated to be $113,158,530.

    Withdrawal of the incentive payment is a form of wage restraint adopted by Government following consultation with the public sector unions. This measure would keep the public sector wage bill at its current level. It is presently a preferred form of wage restraint to freezing of annual increments. The incentive payment amounts to 4% of the annual wage bill and is equivalent to the annual increment in the public sector. Hence, withdrawing the incentive payment would hold down the public sector wage cost at its current level to the same extent as cessation of the annual increments. It is a measure preferred by the Government and the unions. Since withdrawal of the incentive payment does not really reduce public sector wage costs, there should in fact be no reduction in purchasing power of the public officers.

     Dr Wong Kwei Cheong: Sir, may I ask the Minister if the Government is also planning to cut partially or even completely the 13th month AWS payment of Government employees?

     Dr Hu Tsu Tau: Mr Speaker, Sir, there is no present intention.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Sir, may the Minister tell us whether this proposal to cut the half month incentive pay for daily-rated employees has been fully discussed with the union?

     Dr Hu Tsu Tau: Mr Speaker, Sir, I have said that this issue is still under consultation.

Column: 568

COLLAPSE OF PAN-ELECTRIC INDUSTRIES AND SUSPENSION OF
TRADING ON THE STOCK EXCHANGE OF SINGAPORE
(Appointment of Commission of Inquiry)


    13. Mr J.B. Jeyaretnam asked the Minister for Finance whether he will recommend to the President to appoint a Commission of Inquiry to enquire fully into all the events leading to the collapse of Pan-Electric Industries and the suspension of trading on the Stock Exchange of Singapore on the 2nd of December 1985.

We have built up an extremely modern infrastructure - housing for our people, roads, harbours, and these are not to be denigrated.     Why have we encountered this recession? Certain Members have suggested that the only solution is for the Government to get down on its knees and pray to the population and the workers to beg forgiveness and all would be solved. I think that is too laughable to contemplate.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: It is the beginning of your sincerity.

     Dr Hu Tsu Tau: Many ignore completely the factual circumstances which surround us. We are caught up in a sea change in the world industrial scene. Many have accused the Government of having entered into unwise investments, all of which have gone sour nowadays, including shipyards, oil refineries, offshore oil, etc. Why did we do this? If we had not done this, we would not be in the position we are today. It is like saying, for the industrial countries, that railroads in the United States should never have been built because they are no longer being

Column: 637

used now. Or the steam engine should never have been invented because it has been superseded by nuclear power stations. This is a simplistic approach used by some economists or pseudo-economists.

    What we have really seen is a basic change in the industrial world where the old industrial processes are now so common place that anyone with funds can buy the technology. As a result you have a proliferation of capacity in just about every main industry in the world, including oil refineries, petrochemicals, shipyards, what have you, leading to an implosion, if you like, or a recession, and low prices, in just about every sector of these heavy industrial commodities. Column: 638

term solution of our problems, not address ourselves solely to the short and medium term, because what we are facing in the longer term is not just competition from the NICs, like South Korea and Taiwan, but more importantly competition from countries like China and India, with their infinite manpower resources.     I think this provides the background to our basic problems and it is the underlying philosophy in which the Economic Committee has addressed our problems and forms the basis in which this year's Budget was constructed.     I will now move on to addressing the several areas of concern which Members have mentioned over the last two days and these are in four broad categories.

    First, there has been great concern expressed over the proposed cuts in Government manpower by 10% by 1990. The Member for Chong Boon has commented that the staff reduction targets are inconsistent with some of the recommendations of the Economic Committee and that tertiary and technical education institutions should increase their annual intakes and the education system upgraded. I would like to assure the House that I fully understand and appreciate the concern expressed by Members.

    The manpower review and reduction programme should not be viewed narrowly as a cost and numbers-cutting exercise. Economizing on public sector

Column: 639

The need for additional labour for industry and other parts of the private sector may not be so pressing now because of the recession, but will become much more apparent when economic growth resumes. With declining birth rates, the net annual addition to the labour force will be progressively smaller.     I should like to stress four points. First, the 10% staff reduction target applies only to existing functions and services. Manpower requirements for new or expanded programmes and services, including expansion of the tertiary and technical education, will be considered separately. There is therefore no contradiction with the Economic Committee's call to upgrade our educational standards. Secondly, it should be possible to achieve the target without retrenchments and without any deterioration in the quality of service. Where necessary, retraining programmes will be conducted to fit staff to available jobs. There need be no fears that the exercise will add to the unemployment problem. There should also be no deterioration in public services despite reduced manning levels. A 10% reduction over five years while maintaining current services is more or less equivalent to a 2% annual gain in productivity. This is a modest target readily achievable through improvements in work procedures, streamlining of organization structures and greater investment

Column: 640

    Thirdly, I have advised Permanent Secretaries and Chief Executive Officers of statutory boards to approach this exercise with some degree of flexibility. The working group on public sector manpower will coordinate and closely monitor the implementation of the staff review and reduction exercise, and I am sure that there will be no adverse consequences.

    Finally, the success of this exercise will depend on teamwork. There must be close consultation and cooperation among all involved, top management staff, public sector unions and the general public.

    The next subject which was of great concern to Members of this House is the issue of consumption tax. In my Budget statement, I chose my words very carefully and I will repeat them. I said the time may come when it will be necessary to impose consumption taxes as a compensatory tax because of possible future needs to reduce direct taxes. Why is this so? Why have we reduced direct taxes in this Budget? The reasons have been given and set out quite clearly by the Economic Committee and I shall only outline them briefly.

    We are price-takers in this world in the majority of our exports, both goods and services. Therefore, we have to remain competitive with those countries which export to the same markets as we do and, as I mentioned earlier, and with other countries potentially lurking in the background. Therefore, the rationale for ensuring that our exports are competitive is to reduce their pre-tax costs to the lowest possible extent. This means reducing manpower costs where this is possible, urging wage restraint, cutting statutory board levies and charges, and taxes which affect pre-tax operating costs, so that companies will at least have a chance to either break even or make a

Column: 641

profit. Without that, no one is going to buy our services or goods. Even our domestic sector relies on the foreign exchange earned from export sales to finance the purchases of goods which we do not produce locally.

    I will give you an example of a restaurant or a hawker stall, which is a very common activity here. The bulk of the food and the energy we consume is imported. Without export services to pay for these goods, the hawker or the restaurant will be unable to buy the raw material with which to cook his char kway teow or whatever to sell to you and me, so that this service will disappear. So even our domestic services depend on our exports to earn the necessary foreign exchange to keep them going. Hence our great emphasis on ensuring that our export services are competitive.

    After the companies have been helped to at least break even or make money, then they must be taxed at a rate which will make them competitive in the return on investment with other countries who are also recipients of foreign investment; these are well-known, so I need not name them. We also have to ensure that our corporate taxes are competitive with countries with whom we are competing. The Economic Committee has recommended lowering the corporate tax to 30% in the initial stages and later to 25% and 20%. I believe the Member for Whampoa also recommends this. We on the Government side were much more conservative. We believe that at this time a 33% rate is sufficiently competitive, provided we ensure that our pre-tax costs are low. Although, in nominal terms, 33% corporate tax seems higher than taxes in Taiwan or South Korea, in fact, in the hands of the dividend holder or the ultimate recipient of profits from a company, our taxes are effectively not higher because we tax on an imputed basis. In Taiwan and in some countries in Europe, they operate a two-tier tax system where tax is paid on his investment in the company in the form of corporate tax and he also has to pay tax in the form of personal tax when he receives the dividend. So taking into account all

Column: 642

these factors, we have decided that for the moment 33% is adequate. However, Government has said that we will review our tax position periodically and we will ensure that our taxes remain competitive.

    The measures we have taken to cut costs and reduce taxes are not something over which we have a monopoly. Other countries may do the same and if in doing so they render our position uncompetitive, we will have to match in order to maintain our exports, and it is in this connection that the Government has raised the possibility of introducing consumption taxes. It is against the future contingency that, in order to remain competitive in the export markets, we may have to reduce the levies of the statutory boards or direct Government taxes to ensure that foreign and domestic investors will have a decent return on capital in order to create jobs for our people. When direct taxes have to be lowered as a result of competitive pressures, the loss of revenue may have to be offset by the levying of consumption taxes. There may not be an immediate need to do so as other factors need be taken into account and two of these factors have been mentioned by Members. On the expenditure side, we have recourse to the cutting of recurrent costs, which we plan to do. In the future, we will require less expenditure on development as much of our infrastructure is already in place. In the longer term I am hopeful that our development requirements will level off and start to decline. With increased economic activity, it may be possible to reduce direct taxes without necessarily introducing consumption taxes. I think you must accept that as a Government we are pragmatic enough not to do something and then stab ourselves on the back.

    However, to get the idea of a compensatory form of tax accepted by the people if it should prove necessary, it has been decided that we would announce it now because the mechanism for collection could be cumbersome but with the aid of electronic systems nowadays it need not be quite so laborious. But the process of implementation will be time-consuming as we must examine all options and certainly look at all safeguards. I have in the Budget statement said that the needs of the lower

Column: 643

But the idea and the need for it, I think, should be firmly implanted in the minds of our citizens. We are not doing this because we want to make more profits - I will come back to the question of Government profits later - but simply because it is necessary in order to survive. It is not something we want to introduce just to allow ourselves to be lambasted by Members of the Opposition.

    At this point perhaps I should digress a little to talk about profits and whether Government should or should not make profits. When I started to speak I decided to cut short my speech because the Member for Whampoa appears to have pirated most of it. However, it seems to be lasting longer than I thought. I find it incredible that grown people can believe that in a Government like we have in Singapore that Government should not make profits. Profits is a surplus of income over expenditure, no more, no less. If Government did not make profits it would have to tax because it provides services and incurs expenditure which have to be paid for. It ought to make a profit in order to pay for these services. If it does not make profits in this form, then it will have to tax. Therefore, everything we ask for has to be paid for and it has to come from someone else.
